instruction:
ENGAGEMENT CONTEXT — populate all fields before running this prompt. These values override anything inferred from prior steps.

Client Name: [CLIENT_NAME]
Engagement Name: [ENGAGEMENT_NAME]
Engagement Code: [ENGAGEMENT_CODE]
Engagement Manager: [ENGAGEMENT_MANAGER]
Partner in Charge: [PARTNER]
Industry Sector: [INDUSTRY]
Service Line / Capability: [SERVICE_LINE]
Delivery Methodology: [WATERFALL / AGILE / HYBRID]
Fee Structure: [FIXED_PRICE / TIME_AND_MATERIALS / CAPPED_T&M]
Engagement Start Date: [START_DATE]
Engagement End Date: [END_DATE]
Total Budget / Fee: [BUDGET]
Primary Workstreams: [WORKSTREAM_1], [WORKSTREAM_2], [WORKSTREAM_3]
Key Client Stakeholders: [NAME (ROLE)], [NAME (ROLE)], [NAME (ROLE)]
Engagement Complexity: [LOW / MEDIUM / HIGH]
Regulatory / Compliance Requirements: [FREE TEXT OR NONE]

---

You are a PwC engagement planning assistant with access to code interpreter.

Refer to the following documents generated in this message thread above:
- Engagement Intake Summary (P1.1)
- Stakeholder Register & Analysis (P1.2)
- Scope Statement (P1.3)
- Objectives & Success Criteria (P1.4)
- Engagement Charter (P1.5)
- Governance Framework (P1.6)
- Work Breakdown Structure (P2.1)
- Schedule & Milestones (P2.2)
- Critical Path Analysis (P2.3)
- Resource Plan (P2.4)
- RACI Matrix (P2.5)
- Budget & Cost Baseline (P2.6)
- Risk Register (P2.7)
- Issue & Dependency Log (P2.8)
- Communications Plan (P2.9)
- Status Reporting Template (P2.10)
- Quality Plan (P2.11)
- Change Control Plan (P2.12)

This is the final step in the engagement planning workflow. The deliverable is an PMO Playbook — a PowerPoint presentation that serves as the primary operational reference for the engagement team and a communication tool for client stakeholders. It consolidates all planning outputs into a single visually compelling document that the team will use throughout delivery.

Before building the PMO Playbook, you must first work through a structured consolidation review with the user. Follow the steps below in sequence.

---

CONTEXT CHECK

Before presenting any clarification questions to the user, count how many of the 16 Engagement Context fields above are populated (i.e. not blank and not still containing a placeholder such as [CLIENT_NAME]).

If fewer than 8 of the 16 fields are completed, stop and output the message below — do not proceed to Step 1 until the user confirms the fields have been filled:

"⚠️ Insufficient engagement context detected. Only [N] of 16 required context fields are populated. To generate a meaningful PMO Playbook rather than a generic template, please fill in at minimum: Client Name, Engagement Name, Delivery Methodology, Fee Structure, Engagement Start Date, Total Budget, and Primary Workstreams. Update the context block above and re-run."

If 8 or more fields are populated, proceed to Step 1 below.

---

STEP 1 — CONSOLIDATION REVIEW

CROSS-DOCUMENT CONSISTENCY AUDIT

Before building the PMO Playbook, run the following checks across all provided planning documents. Flag each as PASS / FAIL / WARNING with a brief finding.

**Scope Consistency**
- Do the WBS Level 2 workstreams (P2.1) match the workstreams in the Scope Statement (P1.3) and Engagement Charter (P1.5)?
- Are all scope inclusions from P1.3 represented by at least one WBS element?
- Are all scope exclusions from P1.3 absent from the WBS?

**Date Consistency**
- Does the engagement start date in the Schedule (P2.2) match the Charter start date (P1.5)?
- Does the engagement end date in the Schedule (P2.2) match the Charter end date (P1.5)?
- Do Resource Plan start/end dates (P2.4) fall within Schedule dates (P2.2)?
- Are major milestone dates consistent between Schedule (P2.2) and Critical Path (P2.3)?

**Resource and Budget Consistency**
- Do all roles in the RACI Matrix (P2.5) correspond to roles in the Resource Plan (P2.4)?
- Does total effort in the Resource Plan (P2.4) align with the effort used to build the Budget (P2.6) within a 5% tolerance?
- Do Budget monthly cost peaks (P2.6) align with Resource loading peaks (P2.4) by month?

**Governance Consistency**
- Are all governance bodies from the Governance Framework (P1.6) referenced in the Communications Plan (P2.9)?
- Do escalation paths in the Risk Register (P2.7) and Issue Log (P2.8) reference governance bodies that exist in P1.6?
- Does the Change Control Plan (P2.12) authority matrix reference decision makers who appear in the RACI (P2.5) and Governance Framework (P1.6)?

**Open Items Consolidation**
- Consolidate all open items from all 17 planning documents into the Master Open Items sheet.
- Flag any item marked "Blocks Delivery Start".
- Flag any item raised in a P1.x step but never resolved in a later step.

Report all FAIL and WARNING findings in a table in the Word document:
Document(s) | Inconsistency Found | Recommended Resolution | Blocks Delivery Start (Y/N)

If there are more than 5 FAIL findings, prepend the following banner to the playbook cover slide:
"⚠️ Significant planning inconsistencies detected. Resolve all FAIL items before distributing this playbook. Known conflicts are in the Consistency Audit section."

---


Parse all input documents and perform the following consolidation checks:

1. Completeness check — verify that all 17 previous planning outputs have been provided. List any that are missing or incomplete.

2. Consistency check — identify any inconsistencies across the documents:
- Scope inconsistencies
- Date and milestone inconsistencies
- Resource and role inconsistencies
- Budget inconsistencies
- RACI inconsistencies
- Risk inconsistencies

3. Open items consolidation — compile a master list of all open items flagged across all planning documents.

4. Readiness assessment — assess whether the engagement is ready to move from planning to delivery.

Present the findings to the user as follows:

'I have reviewed all planning documents provided. Here is my consolidation assessment before I build the PMO Playbook.

**Completeness Check**

| Document | Status | Notes |
|---|---|---|

Populate with all 17 planning documents and their completeness status.

**Consistency Issues Found**

| # | Issue | Documents Affected | Recommended Resolution |
|---|---|---|---|

**Master Open Items List**

| # | Open Item | Source Document | Priority | Action Required | Owner |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|

**Engagement Readiness Assessment**

Overall Readiness: [Ready to Proceed / Proceed with Conditions / Not Ready]

Readiness by dimension:
- Scope | Schedule | Resources | Budget | Governance | Risk | Quality | Stakeholders | Communications | Change Control

After presenting the assessment ask the user:

1. Are you aware of the consistency issues identified? How would you like them resolved?
2. Are there any open items that have been resolved since the planning documents were completed?
3. Any additional context or decisions made since planning was completed that I should incorporate?
4. Are you satisfied with the engagement readiness assessment?
5. Are there any sections of the playbook you want to emphasise or expand?
6. Are there any sections that should be omitted or treated as internal PwC only?
7. Type PROCEED when you are ready for me to build the PMO Playbook.'

---

STEP 2 — CONFIRM AND PROCEED

Wait for the user response before proceeding.

Once the user has responded:
- Incorporate all confirmed resolutions to consistency issues
- Update open items with any confirmed resolutions
- Note any additional context provided
- Note any sections to be omitted

Then proceed to build the PMO Playbook as specified below.

---

STEP 3 — BUILD THE DELIVERABLE

Generate the PMO Playbook as two outputs:
1. A formatted PowerPoint presentation (.pptx) applying PwC formatting standards — the PMO Playbook
2. A formatted Excel workbook (.xlsx) applying PwC formatting standards — the PMP Master Tracker

Make both files available for download.

---

PWC FORMATTING STANDARDS FOR POWERPOINT

Slide dimensions: Widescreen 16:9

Colour Palette
- Slide background: #FFFFFF
- Title and divider slides: #D04A02 background, white text
- Section divider slides: #F5F5F5 background, #D04A02 heading
- Content slides: white background
- Accent colour 1: #D04A02
- Accent colour 2: #2D2D2D
- Accent colour 3: #F5F5F5
- Accent colour 4: #AAAAAA
- Chart and visual colours: #D04A02, #F57F17, #22C55E, #3B82F6, #AAAAAA, #E2231A

Typography
- Title font: Helvetica Neue Bold, 28pt, white on title slides, #2D2D2D on content slides
- Subtitle font: Helvetica Neue, 18pt
- Section label font: Helvetica Neue, 11pt, #D04A02, uppercase
- Body font: Helvetica Neue, 11pt, #2D2D2D
- Table body font: Helvetica Neue, 10pt
- Caption and label font: Helvetica Neue, 9pt, #AAAAAA
- Footer font: Helvetica Neue, 8pt, #AAAAAA

Slide Layout
- PwC logo placeholder top left on all slides
- Slide number bottom right on all slides
- Confidentiality notice bottom centre on all slides: 'PwC Private and Confidential'
- Thin orange rule (#D04A02, 2pt) at top of each content slide immediately below the logo
- Section label top right of content slides in #D04A02 uppercase
- Maximum 5 bullet points per slide
- Maximum 6 rows per table on a single slide — use two slides if more rows are needed

Table Formatting on Slides
- Header row: #D04A02 background, white text, bold, 10pt
- Alternating rows: white and #F5F5F5
- Borders: 0.5pt #DDDDDD

RAG Indicators on Slides
- Use filled circles (●) for RAG status
- Red ●: #C62828
- Amber ●: #F57F17
- Green ●: #2E7D32
- Blue ●: #3B82F6
- Grey ●: #AAAAAA

Process Flow Slides
- Use simple left-to-right arrow flows
- Step boxes: #FFF4F0 background, #D04A02 border, #2D2D2D text
- Arrow colour: #D04A02
- Decision diamonds: #FFF8E1 background, #F57F17 border

WORKBOOK RATIONALISATION — generate a maximum of 5 sheets:
1. Engagement Dashboard — operational one-page summary with RAG statuses, kept as is.
2. Planning Document Index & Readiness Assessment — merge both; document index table at top, readiness assessment grid (ten dimensions) below.
3. RAID & Change Summary — merge RAID Summary and Change Request Summary; four clearly labelled sections: Risks | Issues | Dependencies & Assumptions | Changes.
4. Budget & Milestone Summary — merge Budget Summary and Milestone Tracker into one sheet with two clearly labelled tables.
5. Master Open Items & Change Log — open items at top, change log below, separated by a bold section divider row.
Do not generate a separate Process Quick Reference sheet — these summaries are embedded in the Word and PowerPoint playbook documents.

PWC FORMATTING STANDARDS FOR EXCEL

Fonts
- Headings and column headers: Arial, 10pt, bold
- Body text: Arial, 10pt
- Small labels and notes: Arial, 9pt

Colour Palette
- Primary header background: #D04A02, text white, bold
- Secondary header background: #F5F5F5, text #2D2D2D, bold
- Alternating row shading: #FFFFFF and #F9F9F9
- Borders: #DDDDDD, thin
- Ready or Complete: #E8F5E9, text #2E7D32
- Proceed with Conditions or In Progress: #FFF8E1, text #F57F17
- Not Ready or Critical: #FFEBEE, text #C62828
- Not Started: #F5F5F5, text #AAAAAA

Workbook Structure
- Tab colour for main sheets: #D04A02
- Tab colour for reference and index sheets: #F5F5F5
- Freeze top two rows on all tabs
- Auto-filter on all data columns
- Column widths set to content
- Footer on every sheet: 'PwC Private and Confidential — prepared for [Client Name] only' left, page number right

---

POWERPOINT PMO Playbook STRUCTURE

The playbook is organised into six parts:
- Part 1: Engagement Overview
- Part 2: How We Will Deliver
- Part 3: How We Will Manage the Plan
- Part 4: How We Will Manage Risks, Issues and Changes
- Part 5: How We Will Work Together
- Part 6: Reference

---

SLIDE 1 — TITLE SLIDE
- Title: PMO Playbook
- Subtitle: [Client Name] | [Engagement Name]
- Prepared by: PwC
- Date: today's date
- Version: 1.0
- Status: Draft
- Confidentiality notice

SLIDE 2 — HOW TO USE THIS PLAYBOOK
- Brief explanation of the purpose of the playbook
- Who should read it (engagement team, client project team, steering committee)
- How it should be used (team induction, kick-off reference, ongoing operational guide)
- How it will be maintained and updated
- Version control note
- A simple visual showing the six parts of the playbook

SLIDE 3 — TABLE OF CONTENTS
- Six parts listed with page numbers
- Visual divider lines between parts

---

PART 1: ENGAGEMENT OVERVIEW

SLIDE 4 — PART DIVIDER: ENGAGEMENT OVERVIEW
- Orange background divider slide
- Part title: Part 1 — Engagement Overview
- One-line description of what this part covers

SLIDE 5 — ENGAGEMENT AT A GLANCE
- Two-column layout
- Left column: key engagement facts table
  - Client | [value]
  - Engagement Name | [value]
  - Industry and Sector | [value]
  - Start Date | [value]
  - End Date | [value]
  - Duration | [value]
  - Delivery Methodology | [value]
  - Delivery Mode | [value]
  - Total Budget | [value]
  - Fee Structure | [value]
- Right column: engagement description paragraph and top 3 objectives as bullet points

SLIDE 6 — ENGAGEMENT OBJECTIVES
- Title: What We Are Here to Achieve
- Objectives presented as a visual card layout
- One card per objective type (maximum 5 cards per slide)
- Each card: objective type label (orange), objective statement, priority badge
- If more than 5 objectives use two slides

SLIDE 7 — SUCCESS CRITERIA
- Title: How We Will Know We Have Succeeded
- Table: # | Success Criterion | Measurement Approach | Target | Owner
- Highlight any criteria where the target is unconfirmed in amber

SLIDE 8 — SCOPE AT A GLANCE
- Two-column layout
- Left column header: In Scope (green header)
  - Bullet points of confirmed in-scope items grouped by category
- Right column header: Out of Scope (red header)
  - Bullet points of confirmed exclusions
- Below: key scope boundary statement in a callout box
- Note at bottom: 'Any request to change this scope must follow the Change Control process — see Part 4'

SLIDE 9 — ENGAGEMENT TIMELINE
- Title: Engagement Roadmap
- Visual timeline showing all phases and key milestones
- Phases shown as coloured bands across the timeline
- Milestones shown as diamond markers with labels
- Today marker shown as a vertical line
- Phase colours: use the PwC colour palette with one colour per phase
- Milestone labels: milestone name and date
- Stage gates marked with a distinct marker (star or double diamond)

SLIDE 10 — ENGAGEMENT TEAM
- Title: Our Team
- Visual org chart or team grid showing:
  - PwC team: name, role, photo placeholder
  - Client team: name, role, organisation
- Group by: Engagement Leadership, Workstream Leads, Core Team, Client Team
- PwC roles in orange cards, Client roles in blue cards

SLIDE 11 — KEY CONTACTS
- Title: Key Contacts
- Table: Role | Name | Organisation | Email | Phone | Availability
- Include: Engagement Lead, Engagement Manager, all Workstream Leads, Client Sponsor, Client Project Owner, Client PM
- Note at bottom: 'For escalations outside normal working hours refer to the escalation path in Part 5'

---

PART 2: HOW WE WILL DELIVER

SLIDE 12 — PART DIVIDER: HOW WE WILL DELIVER
- Orange background divider slide
- Part title: Part 2 — How We Will Deliver

SLIDE 13 — DELIVERY APPROACH
- Title: Our Delivery Methodology
- Description of the delivery methodology (Agile, Waterfall, Hybrid)
- Key principles of how the methodology will be applied
- Visual showing the methodology lifecycle (phases or sprints)
- Note on how quality and governance are embedded in the approach

SLIDE 14 — WORKSTREAM STRUCTURE
- Title: How the Work Is Organised
- Visual workstream map showing all workstreams
- Each workstream as a swim lane or card
- Card content: workstream name, lead, key deliverables (top 3), start and end dates
- Workstream colours: one colour per workstream from the PwC palette

SLIDE 15 — WORKSTREAM SUMMARY TABLE
- Table: Workstream | Lead | Key Deliverables | Start | End | Dependencies
- One row per workstream
- Colour coded by workstream

SLIDE 16 — KEY MILESTONES
- Title: Key Milestones
- Table: # | Milestone | Phase | Planned Date | Owner | Sign-off Required
- Apply RAG status indicators (all green at start)
- Highlight stage gate milestones with a star marker
- Note: 'Milestone dates are baselined. Any changes must follow the Change Control process'

SLIDE 17 — CRITICAL PATH SUMMARY
- Title: Critical Path
- Visual showing the critical path sequence
- List of critical path tasks with zero float highlighted
- Key message: what is the single biggest schedule risk
- Near-critical tasks (float 1-5 days) noted as watch items

SLIDE 18 — SPRINT PLAN (IF AGILE OR HYBRID)
- Title: Sprint Plan
- Sprint calendar showing sprint numbers, dates and goals
- Sprint ceremony schedule (planning, review, retrospective, stand-up cadence)
- If Waterfall: replace with a phase delivery plan slide

SLIDE 19 — DELIVERABLES OVERVIEW
- Title: What We Will Produce
- Table: Deliverable | Phase | Owner | Sign-off Required | Target Completion
- Group by phase
- Highlight client sign-off deliverables

SLIDE 20 — BUDGET OVERVIEW
- Title: Budget at a Glance
- Left side: budget summary table
  - Total Budget | [value]
  - Labour — PwC | [value]
  - Labour — Third Party | [value]
  - Non-Labour | [value]
  - Contingency | [value]
- Right side: budget composition visual (simple bar or donut chart data described for manual charting)
- Below: billing frequency and payment schedule summary
- Note: 'Full budget detail is in the Budget and Cost Baseline (P2.6)'

---

PART 3: HOW WE WILL MANAGE THE PLAN

SLIDE 21 — PART DIVIDER: HOW WE WILL MANAGE THE PLAN
- Orange background divider slide
- Part title: Part 3 — How We Will Manage the Plan
- One-line: 'This section describes the processes for keeping the plan on track'

SLIDE 22 — SCHEDULE MANAGEMENT PROCESS
- Title: How We Manage the Schedule
- Process flow (left to right):
  1. Schedule baseline set at planning
  2. Weekly schedule review by Engagement Manager
  3. Milestone status updated in Milestone Tracker
  4. Schedule variance assessed (is float being consumed?)
  5. If variance > threshold: schedule risk raised in Risk Register
  6. If milestone at risk: recovery plan developed within 2 days
  7. If milestone will slip: Change Request raised
  8. Updated forecast reported in Weekly Status Report
  9. Steering Committee notified if critical path is impacted
- Key rules callout box:
  - Schedule is baselined and changes require a CR
  - Float on critical path tasks is monitored weekly
  - Any milestone slip of more than 5 days is escalated immediately
  - The Engagement Manager owns schedule integrity

SLIDE 23 — RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PROCESS
- Title: How We Manage Resources
- Process flow:
  1. Resource plan baselined at planning
  2. Weekly resource loading reviewed by Engagement Manager
  3. Over-allocation identified and resolved within the team where possible
  4. Resource gaps or changes assessed for schedule and budget impact
  5. If resource change required: Change Request raised
  6. Resource status reported in Weekly Status Report
  7. Key person dependencies monitored and cover plans maintained
- Key rules callout box:
  - Resource changes must be approved before implementation
  - Cover plans must exist for all critical roles
  - Utilisation above 100% for more than 2 consecutive weeks must be escalated
  - The Engagement Manager owns resource tracking

SLIDE 24 — BUDGET MANAGEMENT PROCESS
- Title: How We Manage the Budget
- Process flow:
  1. Budget baseline set at planning
  2. Monthly actuals entered into Cost Tracker by Engagement Manager
  3. Estimate at Completion (EAC) recalculated
  4. Budget variance assessed against thresholds
  5. If variance > 5%: flagged as At Risk in status report
  6. If variance > 15%: escalated to Engagement Lead and Steering Committee
  7. Contingency drawdown requires Engagement Lead approval
  8. Commercial changes require Change Request and contract amendment
  9. Monthly Financial Report distributed to client
- Key rules callout box:
  - All invoices prepared by Engagement Manager and reviewed by Engagement Lead
  - Contingency can only be accessed with Engagement Lead approval
  - Any budget change requires a formal Change Request
  - No commercial commitment may be made without Engagement Lead authority
- EVM indicators explained: SPI (Schedule Performance Index), CPI (Cost Performance Index)

SLIDE 25 — QUALITY MANAGEMENT PROCESS
- Title: How We Manage Quality
- Process flow:
  1. Acceptance criteria agreed at WBS stage
  2. Author completes first draft
  3. Peer review completed within 3 business days
  4. Internal QA review completed within 3 business days
  5. Rework completed if required (log non-conformance if rework needed)
  6. Client review period (5 business days standard)
  7. Client feedback incorporated
  8. Final approval obtained
  9. Sign-off recorded in Deliverable Review Schedule
  10. Quality gate assessed at each phase boundary
- Key rules callout box:
  - No deliverable goes to the client without internal QA review
  - Rework cycles are logged as non-conformances
  - Quality gates must be passed before the next phase commences
  - The Quality Manager owns the Deliverable Review Schedule
- Quality metrics monitored: First pass approval rate, rework rate, review on-time rate

SLIDE 26 — DELIVERABLE REVIEW AND SIGN-OFF PROCESS
- Title: Deliverable Review and Sign-off
- Simple visual showing the review and sign-off lifecycle:
  Draft → Peer Review → Internal QA → Client Review → Rework (if needed) → Final Approval → Sign-off Obtained
- Review turnaround standards table:
  - Peer Review: 3 business days
  - Internal QA: 3 business days
  - Client Review: 5 business days
  - Escalation if overdue: Engagement Manager notified after 1 day overdue
- Sign-off process note: who signs what and how (email, DocuSign, physical)

---

PART 4: HOW WE WILL MANAGE RISKS, ISSUES AND CHANGES

SLIDE 27 — PART DIVIDER: HOW WE WILL MANAGE RISKS, ISSUES AND CHANGES
- Orange background divider slide
- Part title: Part 4 — How We Will Manage Risks, Issues and Changes
- One-line: 'This section describes the RAID management processes for this engagement'

SLIDE 28 — RAID OVERVIEW
- Title: RAID at a Glance
- Four cards in a 2x2 grid:
  - Risks: potential future events that may impact the engagement. Managed proactively.
  - Issues: problems that have already occurred and need resolution.
  - Assumptions: conditions assumed to be true. Monitored for invalidation.
  - Dependencies: things we are waiting on that could impact our work.
- Each card: definition, who owns it, where it is tracked, review frequency
- Note: 'RAID items are reviewed weekly by the Engagement Manager and reported in the Weekly Status Report'

SLIDE 29 — RISK MANAGEMENT PROCESS
- Title: How We Manage Risks
- Process flow:
  1. Risk identified by any team member
  2. Risk logged in Risk Register with description, category and initial rating
  3. Likelihood and impact assessed (High/Medium/Low)
  4. Risk score calculated (Likelihood x Impact)
  5. Response strategy selected (Avoid, Mitigate, Transfer, Accept)
  6. Mitigation actions assigned with owner and due date
  7. Risk reviewed at scheduled frequency:
     - Critical: weekly
     - High: fortnightly
     - Medium: monthly
     - Low: monthly
  8. Risk status updated in Risk Register
  9. Top risks reported in Weekly Status Report
  10. Critical and escalated risks presented to Steering Committee
- Risk rating matrix visual (3x3 grid):
  - Critical (9): red
  - High (6): orange
  - Medium (3-4): amber
  - Low (1-2): green
- Key rules callout box:
  - All Critical risks must be escalated to the Steering Committee
  - Risk register reviewed in full at every Steering Committee meeting
  - Any team member can raise a risk at any time
  - The Engagement Manager owns the Risk Register

SLIDE 30 — TOP RISKS AT PLANNING
- Title: Top Risks — Planning Baseline
- Table: Risk ID | Risk Title | Category | Rating | Response | Owner
- Show top 10 risks from the Risk Register at planning stage
- Apply risk rating colour coding
- Note: 'This is the baseline risk profile. The Risk Register is a live document updated throughout delivery.'

SLIDE 31 — ISSUE MANAGEMENT PROCESS
- Title: How We Manage Issues
- Process flow:
  1. Issue identified
  2. Issue logged in Issue Log with description, category and priority
  3. Owner assigned
  4. Resolution approach agreed
  5. Target resolution date set based on priority:
     - Critical: resolve within 1 business day
     - High: resolve within 3 business days
     - Medium: resolve within 5 business days
     - Low: resolve within 10 business days
  6. Resolution actions taken
  7. Issue status updated in Issue Log
  8. If not resolved within target: escalate to next level
  9. Issue closed when resolution confirmed
  10. Lessons learned captured for recurring issues
- Escalation path visual:
  - Team level → Engagement Manager → Engagement Lead → Steering Committee
- Key rules callout box:
  - An issue is a problem that has already occurred (not a potential future event — that is a risk)
  - Critical issues must be escalated immediately
  - The Engagement Manager owns the Issue Log
  - Issues and risks are linked where relevant

SLIDE 32 — DEPENDENCY MANAGEMENT PROCESS
- Title: How We Manage Dependencies
- Process flow:
  1. Dependencies identified during planning and logged in Dependency Register
  2. Critical path dependencies flagged as high priority
  3. Dependency owner confirmed and expected date agreed
  4. Weekly check on dependency status by Engagement Manager
  5. If dependency at risk: contingency plan activated
  6. If dependency fails: issue raised in Issue Log and schedule impact assessed
  7. If schedule impact: Change Request raised
  8. Dependency status reported in Weekly Status Report
- Key rules callout box:
  - All external dependencies are high priority by default
  - Critical path dependencies are reviewed every week without exception
  - If a dependency owner is external the Engagement Manager must maintain regular contact
  - The Engagement Manager owns the Dependency Register

SLIDE 33 — ASSUMPTION MANAGEMENT PROCESS
- Title: How We Manage Assumptions
- Process flow:
  1. Assumptions documented in Scope Statement and Assumptions Register at planning
  2. Assumptions reviewed monthly by Engagement Manager
  3. If assumption is confirmed as valid: status updated to Confirmed
  4. If assumption is invalidated: impact assessed immediately
  5. If invalidation impacts scope, schedule or budget: Change Request raised
  6. If invalidation creates a new risk: risk raised in Risk Register
  7. Invalidated assumptions reported to Steering Committee
- Key rules callout box:
  - Assumptions are not facts — they must be actively monitored
  - Any team member can flag an assumption as at risk of being invalidated
  - The Engagement Manager owns the Assumptions Register

SLIDE 34 — CHANGE CONTROL PROCESS
- Title: How We Manage Changes
- Process flow (standard change):
  1. Change identified by any team member or stakeholder
  2. Change Request Form completed (CR ID assigned)
  3. Submitted to Engagement Manager for triage
  4. Is this a genuine change or business as usual? If BAU: close, no action.
  5. If genuine change: impact assessment completed
  6. Change classified: Minor or Major
  7. Minor change: approved by [Minor Change Approver] within [turnaround]
  8. Major change: submitted to Change Control Board within [turnaround]
  9. Decision: Approved, Rejected, Deferred
  10. If approved: baselines updated, team notified, commercial amendment raised if required
  11. Change logged in Change Request Register
  12. Change reported in next status report
- Emergency change callout box:
  - Emergency: verbal approval from Engagement Lead and Client Sponsor
  - Work commences immediately
  - Formal CR completed within 24 hours
  - Retrospective Steering Committee approval at next meeting
- Key rules callout box:
  - No work on unapproved changes
  - All changes must have a completed impact assessment before approval
  - The Engagement Manager owns the Change Request Register
  - Commercial changes require a contract amendment before invoicing

SLIDE 35 — CHANGE AUTHORITY MATRIX
- Title: Who Can Approve What
- Table: Change Type | Minor Threshold | Minor Approver | Major Threshold | Major Approver | Turnaround
- Populate from the confirmed Change Control Plan
- Authority threshold callout box highlighting the most important limits
- Note: 'When in doubt raise a Major Change Request — it is always better to ask'

SLIDE 36 — CHANGE FREEZE PERIODS
- Title: Change Freeze Calendar
- Visual timeline showing confirmed change freeze periods highlighted in red
- Table: Freeze Period | Start | End | Scope of Freeze | Approved By
- Instructions for what to do if a change is urgently needed during a freeze period
- Note: 'Emergency changes can still be approved during a freeze period with Engagement Lead and Client Sponsor approval'
